channel.title: Digg Long Reads Stories
channel.description: Digg - What the Internet is talking about right now

item.title: At The Limits Of Thought
item.description: Science today stands at a crossroads: will its progress be driven by human minds or by the machines that we've created?

item.title: The Crash Of The $8.5 Billion Global Flower Trade
item.description: As people everywhere cancel events and big cut-flower orders, the ripples reach into Dutch auction halls and Kenyan rose fields.

item.title: Loneliness Is Other People
item.description: For the single among us, the advent of coronavirus was like a game of musical chairs: in an instant, the people we were casually dating were the people we were stuck with — whether we liked them or not.

item.title: The King Who Became A Pirate
item.description: When King Erik VII of Denmark was forced from the throne, he did the only thing any self-respecting descendent of Vikings could: He joined the warriors of the sea and hit right back at his enemies.

item.title: The Atoll At The Center Of The World
item.description: What Lies Ahead for the Marshall Islands?

item.title: I Sampled My Way Through The Wild World Of High-End Cannabis Products
item.description: If luxury THC granola, weed aperitifs and CBD pillows couldn't make me into a stoner, nothing can.

item.title: New York Needed Ventilators. So They Developed One In A Month
item.description: The pandemic inspired an innovative project to design and make a low-cost ventilator in weeks, not years.

item.title: It's Not Too Late To Go On Offense Against The Coronavirus
item.description: To end the nightmare, lockdowns aren't enough. We need to hunt the virus and defeat it.

item.title: The Coronavirus Pandemic Has Put Gen Z And Young Millennials' Lives On Hold
item.description: During our lifetimes, the US has always felt like it was in crisis. I talked with nine young millennials and Gen Z'ers about what the coronavirus pandemic means for their futures.

item.title: Whole Foods Is Quietly Tracking Its Employees With A Heat Map Tool That Ranks Which Stores Are Most At Risk Of Unionizing
item.description: Amazon-owned Whole Foods is quietly tracking its employees with a heat map tool that ranks which stores are most at risk of unionizing

item.title: She Kept Getting Close To Music Stardom. Then Her Body And Mind Started To Fail Her
item.description: Zai sticks in your mind like a celebrity — a live-action anime heroine, an Instagram avatar come to life — except she's not. She's not even close. And the more time you spend with her, the mystery of why only deepens.

item.title: Three Nights With 311 During The Onset Of The Coronavirus
item.description: For 311's 30th anniversary, the band took over the Park MGM in Las Vegas, playing 102 songs over three nights with no repeats. Our writer went to the desert on the eve of a pandemic to meet the superfans of America's most positive band — and figure out why he stopped loving them.

item.title: To Run My Best Marathon At Age 44, I Had To Outrun My Past
item.description: After 20 years of long-distance competition, I ran my fastest. All it took was tech, training and a new understanding of my life.

item.title: The Complicated Truths Of Dr. Dre's 'The Chronic'
item.description: No rap album has quite the mythology attached to it — as a game changer, a king maker, a genre expander. But legends aren't exactly fact.

item.title: Inside Army Ranger School, A 61-Day Laboratory Of Human Endurance
item.description: The military's toughest training challenges have a lot in common with outdoor sufferfests like the Barkley Marathons and the Leadville Trail 100: you have to be fit and motivated to make the starting line, but your mind and spirit are what carry you to the end.

item.title: A Shot In Hell
item.description: Should Las Vegas's machine-gun rental industry be the future liberals want for assault weapons?

item.title: 25 Years After Oklahoma City, Domestic Terrorism Is On The Rise
item.description: In an exclusive interview with WIRED, FBI director Christopher Wray discusses a scourge that "moves at the speed of social media."

item.title: The Coronavirus In America: The Year Ahead
item.description: More than 20 experts in public health, medicine and history shared their thoughts on the future. Most believed that once the crisis was over, the nation and its economy would revive quickly. But there would be no escaping a period of intense pain.

item.title: The Life And Death Of Juan Sanabria, One Of New York City's First Coronavirus Victims
item.description: The fifty-two-year-old doorman from the Bronx was a beloved mainstay at 860 Grand Concourse—until he got sick.

item.title: The Uplifting Tale Of These Tiny Island Foxes, Nearly Wiped Out By Disaster
item.description: Earth Day began after a catastrophe off California. Leadership and science restored nature and hope through years of despair and controversy.

item.title: The Untold Story Of America's Biggest Coronavirus Outbreak
item.description: How did the biggest cluster in the US emerge in a corner of South Dakota? Infections spread like wildfire through a pork factory and questions remain about what the company did to protect staff.

item.title: Inside The Ship That Stands Watch Over The Melting Arctic
item.description: You can tell the Norwegian research vessel Johan Hjort is made for the Arctic because it holds a tanning bed inside.

item.title: Donald Trump's Greatest Escape
item.description: His critics assume this crisis has to take Trump down, whether for the bungled response or the economic collapse. They're missing something important: He's been training for this moment his entire life.

item.title: Everyone Is Trying To Sell Medical Equipment — Even On LinkedIn
item.description: With face masks and other protective gear in short supply, speculators and pop-up brokers are finding customers on an unlikely platform.

item.title: How You'll Grocery Shop After The Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: The coronavirus will change grocery stores, and probably not for the better.

item.title: 'Teenage Dirtbag' 2.0
item.description: Wheatus' anthem of teenage alienation has grown into an enduring cult classic. So why has the band spent the past year re-creating it note-for-note?

item.title: Costco Is Thriving During The Coronavirus Pandemic. Its Workers Say They've Paid The Price
item.description: Costco has long been beloved by employees, some of whom have worked there for decades. But the retailer's decision-making during the coronavirus pandemic has tested their loyalty and compromised their health.

item.title: Carnival Executives Knew They Had A Virus Problem, But Kept The Party Going
item.description: At least 1,500 people on the company's cruise ships have been diagnosed with COVID-19, dozens have died, and the lawsuits are just getting started.

item.title: Michigan's Ex-Gov. Rick Snyder Knew About Flint's Toxic Water — And Lied About It
item.description: Six years after the city of Flint, Michigan, began using a toxic water source that sickened its residents, VICE uncovered payoffs, the silencing of a whistleblower, a shady financial deal, a coverup, and the former governor who presided over it all.

item.title: The Black Plague
item.description: Public officials lament the way that the coronavirus is engulfing black communities. The question is, what are they prepared to do about it?

item.title: Coronavirus Antibody Tests Could Help Us Get Back To Normal — Or They Could Be The Next Testing Crisis
item.description: Hospitals and clinics are rushing to use antibody tests in an effort to determine who is immune to the coronavirus. But almost none of them have been verified by the FDA.

item.title: A $2 Billion Settlement And The Lawyer Whose Clients Didn't Exist
item.description: A well-known attorney helped land a $2 billion settlement for Gulf Coast seafood-industry workers after the BP oil spill. But who was he really representing?

item.title: Unholy Anorexia
item.description: Medieval mystics starved the body to feed the soul. Understanding this perfectionist mindset could help treat anorexia today.

item.title: An Army Of Virus Tracers Takes Shape In Massachusetts
item.description: Asian countries have invested heavily in digital contact-tracing, which uses technology to warn people when they have been exposed to the coronavirus. Massachusetts is using an old-fashioned means: people.

item.title: How A Pudgy Porpoise May Save Other Animals From Extinction
item.description: The vaquita, an icon of the Gulf of California, is swiftly dying out. But its strange DNA could hold valuable lessons for other threatened species.

item.title: Telemedicine Is Not Enough
item.description: It's 2020, and millions of Americans — now bound to their homes — still don't have reliable internet access. In a pandemic, that's a public health crisis.

item.title: Uncovering Operation NEPTUN, The Cold War's Most Daring Disinformation Campaign
item.description: Rumored Nazi treasure, a dark Bohemian lake, an unsuspecting TV crew — and a brilliant spy to put it all together.

item.title: Finally We May Have A Path To The Fundamental Theory Of Physics... And It's Beautiful
item.description: How does our universe work? Scientist Stephen Wolfram opens up his ongoing Wolfram Physics Project to a global effort. His team will livestream work in progress, post working materials, release software tools and hold educational programs.

item.title: What Happens When The White House Press Secretary Is Invisible: The Short, Strange Tale Of Stephanie Grisham
item.description: In her nine months on the job, Grisham never held a White House press briefing.

item.title: The Pentagon's Plan To Build A Secret Super Command Bunker 3,500 Feet Under Washington DC
item.description: Unlike any fortification on earth, the Deep Underground Command Center was intended to withstand multiple direct hits from giant nukes on Doomsday.

item.title: The True Story Of The White Island Eruption
item.description: Last December, around 100 tourists set out for New Zealand's Whakaari / White Island. It was supposed to be a routine six-hour tour, including the highlight: a quick hike into the island's otherworldly caldera. Then the volcano exploded.

item.title: Inside Kanye West's Vision For The Future
item.description: Kanye West says he's redesigning the very building blocks of family life — food, clothing, and shelter — and he's claimed thousands of acres in Wyoming as a test site for his ideas.

item.title: The Devastating Decline Of A Brilliant Young Coder
item.description: Lee Holloway programmed internet security firm Cloudflare into being. But then he became apathetic, distant, and unpredictable — for a long time, no one could make sense of it.

item.title: Inside the High Stakes New Life of a Coronavirus Specialist | GQ
item.description: For years, ​Timothy Sheahan​ was an expert in a field you paid no attention to. Now, he's doing some of the most important work on the planet — racing around the clock to find a coronavirus cure.​​​​

item.title: This Economist Has A Radical Plan To Solve Wealth Inequality
item.description: French economist Thomas Piketty says inequality is a political choice. The solution? Wealth taxes well beyond anything dreamed up by Bernie Sanders.

item.title: The Naval Academy's War With a Professor Who Sends Shirtless Pics, Offends Women And Minorities — And Somehow Came Out On Top
item.description: From ivory-tower faculty lounges to the Pentagon, Bruce Fleming is known for being a chauvinistic, egoistic loudmouth. Also, one hardened warrior.

item.title: Timeline Of The Coronavirus Pandemic And US Response
item.description: In response to COVID-19, the US was slow to act at a time when each day of inaction mattered most. Here's a comprehensive timeline.

item.title: How This Dubious 'Doctor' Became 'The Most Quoted Human On The Planet'
item.description: Steve Maraboli has spent the last two decades building an online empire of self-mythology — and it's almost entirely false.

item.title: The Anxious Child And The Crisis Of Modern Parenting
item.description: How to raise a resilient child in 2020

item.title: How Coronavirus Almost Brought Down The Global Financial System
item.description: The crisis has brought the economy to a near halt, and left millions of people out of work. But thanks to intervention on an unprecedented scale, a full-scale meltdown has been averted — for now.
